pullRequest.body:
Lays the groundwork for a proof of equivalence of RE and NFA, w.r.t. described language. Actual connection to REs comes later, after the groundwork for the opposite direction has been laid.

Third chunk of #12648

---

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message

Deletions:

- ...

below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

nodes.body:
### PR summary [199b0c36e0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15651/commits/199b0c36e0795076c54821456072e10b69de4153)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ char`
`+ char_correct`
`+ evalFrom_append`
`+ evalFrom_subset`
`+ hadd_correct`
`+ hmul_correct`
`+ hmul_eval₁`
`+ hmul_eval₂`
`+ instance : HAdd (NFA α σ) (NFA α σ') (NFA α (σ ⊕ σ'))`
`+ instance : HMul (NFA α σ) (NFA α σ') (NFA α (σ ⊕ σ'))`
`+ instance : One (NFA α σ)`
`+ instance : Zero (NFA α σ)`
`+ kstar`
`+ kstar_correct`
`+ kstar_eval`
`+ kstar_eval_aux`
`+ one_correct`
`+ zero_correct`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

I think it's a bit strange to have this defined in terms of `default`, which is meant to be an arbitrary element of the type with no special meaning. I think it would be best to move this instance to the top of the file and then define the `Inhabited` instance as `⟨0⟩` and replace uses of `default` further down by `0`.

Thank you for pointing that out! I didn't want to upend the sectioning of the file, so I instead moved the `Inhabited` instance down so it can use `⟨0⟩`. The uses of `default` further down refer to the states, which can, inherently, not depend on implementation details of `σ/σ'`.

A silly thought that occured to me to really drive the point of not relying on the particulars of `default` home was to just use `1`, which doesn't need `σ` to be `Inhabited` to be defined but has differing semantics depending on whether or not `σ` actually is.

```suggestion
/-- An NFA accepting just a single word of length 1, given by the underlying character. -/
def char (a : α) : NFA α (σ ⊕ σ') :=
  ⟨fun p c q ↦ p.isLeft ∧ a = c ∧ q.isRight, (Sum.isLeft ·), (Sum.isRight ·)⟩
```
Also, I don't really understand why we need `σ` and `σ'` around here. Why not just `Fin 2` as the set of states?

It is a bit awkward, to be sure. I wanted to stay as generic as possible and what really matters about the `char` automaton's state type is that it has at least two distinct elements. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be a data-carrying pendant to `Nontrivial`, like `Inhabited` is to `Nonempty`. There is `TwoPointing`, but that's not a class…

`Fin 2` (or `Bool` or whatever) would lock the state space in place.
This way, one can't just conjure up a three-stated `char` automaton and re-use the `char_correct` proof (if that is ever on someone's mind).
It also raises the question of why the `One` instance doesn't just work with `Fin 1`/`Unit` or `Zero` with `Fin 0`/`Empty`.

But in the end, I'm really curious to find out what “the mathlib approach”™ would be. I see four different ways to proceed here:
1. make `TwoPointing` a class (adding another PR?)
2. use an `Inhabited σ` and let `char` work with `Option σ`
3. keep the sum
4. use a specific state type (and have a think about `Zero`/`One`?)

I would be glad to receive some input and/or additions!

```suggestion
private lemma kstar_eval_aux {P : NFA α σ} {y} (h : y ∈ P.accepts) :
```
unless you are going to use this in another file? in which case it should be better named instead

Thanks, I didn't know about the `private` keyword and thought `lemma` would be enough to signify the intention of being only immediately useful. I shall add the keyword, then. The other `lemma`ta might come in useful in other places though, since they describe interactions with `eval` somewhat more completely. Or would you prefer them being made private, as well?
I think the other ones shouldn't be private, unless you rename them to something like `_aux`  (and I don't see why you would do that)
Hmm, I'm not a huge fan of this notation. Is this not called "concatenation" informally?

I've leaned on the notation for Kleene algebras, where + is the union and * is concatenation. `hadd_correct` and `hmul_correct` illustrate this. Or would you like me to avoid notation in general? I could certainly make `union` and `concat` (or whatever) functions out of these definitions. (As was already necessary for `kstar`.)

Heterogeneous addition is so far not used in mathlib, so I am a bit wary of introducing a use of it. I don't want to be dogmatic, so my personal opinion is that removing the notation might be the best thing to do. I would suggest calling the definition `sum` to match the `⊕` that appears in the return type.

pullRequest.title: feat(Computability/NFA): operations for Thompson's construction

source.title: feat(Computability): language-preserving maps between NFA and RE
